unicode.value:
Hello! Welcome to this activity about the THIRD CONDITIONAL.

Are you checking this topic in class? Are you here just out of curiosity? Well, as long as you want to learn, it doesn't matter. Let's do this!

Survey
What am I going to learn?

With this activity you are going to learn the use of the third conditional and how to structure it. All this with the help of Courage the Cowardly dog.

This activity is aimed at B1 level students.

It is not necessary for you to know about or remember the other conditionals, although I am sure you have seen some of them.

What youÂ Â need to know for this activity is:

  • Past Perfect tense
  • The participle form of verbs
  • Basic knowledge of modal verbs

First of all, letâs review what a conditional is.

As you may know, there are 4 types of conditionals: 0, 1st, 2nd and the one we are about to see. They are also calledÂ if clauses because of a part of its structure, and this can help you to spot these types of sentences.

All conditionals are formed by two sentences or clauses: the if clause, which is the condition, and the main clause, which would be the result of the stated condition.

As we see in the image, we can start with the if clause and then put the main clause or vice versa, just pay attention to the fact that we put a comma (,) in the middle of the sentences if we put the if clause first.

Now that we remembered this information letâs focus on the third conditional.

When do we use it? We use the third conditional to express past wishes or events that are unreal. Thatâs why it is also called the Unreal Conditional. For example:

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  If I had saved my money, I would have bought a small car. (But in reality I hadnât saved any money, so it is a wish or an imaginary scenario.)

We can change the order and the meaning does not change. Just notice that in this case the comma is not necessary.

Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â I would have bought a small car if I had saved my money.

What is its structure?Â 

*The modal would is the most common but we can use could or might. And remember that the modal and the word have can be contracted as well = wouldâve, couldâveâ¦

The negation goes in the auxiliary and the modal. As you see it can be contracted.

Let's see some examples:

So, as you see, all these situations are unreal, because in the end they did end up in the middle of nowhere with Eustace using a mask and scaring Courage.
Look at the following document with some images of an episode of Courage the cowardly dog. Then answer the activities related to this.
I would have been better if...
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Courage has some past wishes. Complete the sentences with the missing words and the correct conjugation of the verbs given, remember the correct structure of the third conditional. For this exercise do NOT use contractions.
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

• If Courage had not seen Â (see) the horror movie, he would not have had nightmares.
  • Courage would not have had stomachache if he had not eaten Â (eat) too much food.
  • If Courage had bought Â (buy) enough apples, Muriel would not have gone to buy more at night.
  • Eustace would not have been kidnapped if Courage had not fallen Â (fell) asleep.
  • If Courage had closed Â (close) the front door, the monstersÂ  would not have entered Â (enter) to the house.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

• If Courage had not seen Â (see) the horror movie, he would not have had nightmares.
  • Courage would not have had stomachache if he had not eaten Â (eat) too much food.
  • If Courage had bought Â (buy) enough apples, Muriel would not have gone to buy more at night.
  • Eustace would not have been kidnapped if Courage had not fallen Â (fell) asleep.
  • If Courage had closed Â (close) the front door, the monstersÂ would not have entered Â (enter) to the house.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
"Find the .txt file (in the applet file) and open it. Copy the contents of this file <ctrl A, ctrl C> into the applet code field.
Add all the files provided for the applet except the .txt file one at a time using the add files and upload buttons. The files, once loaded will be displayed beneath the Applet code field.

If the applet you're adding was generated by one of the programs in this drop down, please select it, then add the data/applet file generated by your program.

eg. For Geogebra applets, select geogebra, then add the .ggb file that you created in Geogebra.

Look at the video and try to construct a chain of events like the one in the first activities. Write at least 7 sentences in your notebook. Remember the correct structure and punctuation. When you finish you can ask your teacher to see if you have mistakes.

Last of the starmakers

Let's review what we have learned.

Â  Â 1. The purpose or function of the THIRD CONDITIONAL is to express past wishes and unreal events = actions that already happened and we are thinking that it could have been different (result) if we had done something else (condition).Â 

Â  Â 2. The easiest way not to get confused is to place the "if" in one clause and the "modal+have" in the other.

Â  Â 3. The negation goes after the auxiliary had in the if clause and after the modal in the main clause.

Â  Â 4. Remember that the punctuation is also important: put a comma when we start with the "if" clause, and don't forget the final period.

I hope that you've learned everything you needed to know. Â Keep practicing to become an expert on this topic!

DuraciÃ³n:
10:00

To finish this activity you will answer a validation quiz. It is important to consider these things:

Â  Â  Â  1. To get this activity validated, you must score at least 80% in this quiz.

Â  Â  Â  2. In order not to lose points, it is important to check not only your answer but your spelling too.

Click here:Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â validation quiz
